column1: #Text=( née Maxwell ; died 28 March 1803 ) , was an 18th-century Scottish author .
#Text=She was the younger sister of Jane Gordon , Duchess of Gordon .
#Text=Eglantine was the youngest daughter of Sir William Maxwell , 3rd Baronet , of Monreith , Wigtownshire .

#Text=A boisterous hoyden in her youth , and a woman of violent temper in her maturer years , she was married on 4 September 1770 to Thomas Dunlop , son of John Dunlop of Dunlop and Frances Anna Wallace , the daughter and heiress of Sir Thomas Wallace ( 1702 – 1770 ) of Craigie , fifth and last baronet .

#Text=On his grandfather 's death in 1770 , her husband inherited Craigie , took the surname Wallace , and assumed the style of a baronet ; however , the property was deeply indebted , and in 1783 he was obliged to sell all that remained of Craigie .
#Text=It would seem to have been shortly after this that Eglantine obtained a legal separation , on the ground , it is said , of her husband 's cruelty .
#Text=It is probable that the quarrel was due to pecuniary embarrassment . [ 1 ]
#Text=Lady Wallace was herself summoned for assaulting a woman — apparently a humble companion — and was directed by the magistrate to compound the matter .
#Text=Leaving Edinburgh , she seems to have settled in London , but upon her play The Whim ( 1795 ) being prohibited the stage by the licenser , she left England in disgust .
#Text=In October 1789 she was arrested at Paris as an English agent , and narrowly escaped with her life .
#Text=There she contracted a friendship with General Charles François Dumouriez , whom in 1793 she entertained in London , where she seems to have been well received in society .
#Text=She died at Munich on 28 March 1803 , leaving two sons , the elder of whom was General [ Sir ]
#Text=Letter to a Friend , with a Poem called the Ghost of Werter
#Text=, 8vo , 1788 ; it was produced at Covent Garden on 8 April 1788 with a good cast , but , according to John Genest , was " very dull " and a dead failure .
#Text=The Conduct of the King of Prussia and General Dumouriez
#Text=, 1793 , 8vo ; this was followed by a separately issued ‘ Supplement . ’
#Text=An Address to the People on Peace and Reform
#Text=This article incorporates text from a publication now in the public domain : Laughton , John Knox ( 1899 ) .
#Text=Jones 's continuation of Baker 's Biographica Dramatica , p.733 , where she is said to have been the wife of Sir James Wallace ;
#Text=' s History of the Counties of Ayr and Wigton , I. i. 296 ;
#Text=Paterson 's Lands and their Owners in Galloway , i. 285 ;
#Text=There are several autobiographical notes in The Conduct of the King of Prussia and General Dumouriez .
